sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: You're watching Euronews tonight. I'm Mariam Zahidi and these are the headlines this hour.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Mariupol continues to be the focus of Russia's eastern offensive as reports emerge of a possible chemical attack on the port city, something the US says it can't confirm and Russia denies happening.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: President Putin says the military operation in Ukraine is going as planned as he vows that Russia's goals will be achieved.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Several people have been shot inside a New York City subway station. Here in the Cube, we're across the latest.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: The Prime Minister Boris Johnson, his wife and the Chancellor of the Exchequer Rishi Sunak are all fined by the police for breaching COVID rules during lockdown.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Good evening. Fighting is continuing in eastern Ukraine as the battle for control of the besieged port city of Mariupol appears to be reaching a critical stage. Fierce fighting rages in the Azovstal industrial district as Russian troops inch closer to the port. UK and US governments are also working to verify reports of a possible

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Russian chemical attack. It follows claims from Ukrainian authorities that three soldiers had been affected by a poisonous substance. The Pentagon says it cannot confirm the attacks but admitted that the potential use of chemical weapons in Ukraine is deeply concerning.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Russia denies the allegations.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: President Volodymyr Zelensky has accused the EU of not providing Ukraine with enough weapons to repel Russian attacks.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Addressing the Lithuanian parliament, Zelensky stressed that lives were being lost and called on Brussels to help bolster Ukraine's war effort.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: It comes as a new report from the UN says nearly two-thirds of all Ukrainian children have been displaced since the start of Russia's invasion.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Meanwhile, Russia's President Vladimir Putin declared that he had made the right decision to invade Ukraine and vowed to calmly press on.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Following a visit to the Vostok Cosmodrome spaceport in Russia's Far East with his Belarusian counterpart Alexander Lukashenko, Putin insisted that Moscow will not be isolated.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: He says Western sanctions have failed to disarm the Kremlin's war machine and described its ambitions as clear and noble.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: VLADIMIR PUTIN, Ukrainian Foreign Minister, We know that today our officers are participating in the special military operation in the Donbass in Ukraine, providing assistance to the peoples' republics of Donbass.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: They are courageous, competent, efficient, and they effectively use the most modern types of weapons with unique, unparalleled characteristics.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Well, for more, let's now bring in our correspondent, Sasha Vakulina, who joins me in the studio.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Sasha, always good to see you.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: So, President Putin is saying that Russia is not going to stop until it achieves its goals.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: We know they're concentrating their offensive in the east, in particular the port city of Mariupol. So how long can Mariupol hold out?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Well we have seen over the past couple of days, specifically yesterday and today, there have been reports that the battle for Mariupol is nearing its end. These reports were called fake by Ukrainian officials. They say that the Ukrainian forces that are still in the city in central part and in the port, the part of the port of Mariupol, they're still holding out against Russia. So this is the official information by Ukrainian officials. We also heard earlier from Ukraine's forces commander in chief. He said that military still had stable open lines of communication with the soldiers inside Mariupol. As well, Zelensky, president of Ukraine, said that Ukraine and Ukrainian forces could deblock Mariupol. As well, Zelensky, president of Ukraine, said that Ukraine and Ukrainian forces could deblock Mariupol, they could go there, but they do need for that to have more weapons and more planes and more help from Western allies. And Sasha, last night we began seeing reports of a possible chemical attack in Mariupol. Now, the U.S. says that it cannot confirm the reports, but Russia has used chemicals in previous battles hasn't it?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Yes that's it. So it cannot be investigated and all the sides are saying the same because for that the investigation into the use of chemical weapons is really complicated. There should be a special commission by the organisation for the prohibition of chemical weapons. They have to be on site. This is not possible, of course, in Mariupol. Now, Ukrainian officials, that was the Ukrainian deputy minister of defense, said based on preliminary data, there's an assumption this could have been phosphorus munition. Now, this is tricky. Phosphorus is not classed as chemical weapons unless it is used close to civilians. Then it is illegal. Russia denies all the accusations.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: The country also says that it destroyed the last weapons, chemical weapons stocks back in 2017.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: But even since then, there were two cases of Russia using chemical weapons.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: And then, of course, there is Syria, where Russia got involved and also with the usage of chemical weapons.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: And Western analysts are saying here that this is called sort of Syrian playbook. Well, Russia could try now when it comes to chemical weapons to go first little, like small, deniable operations, which West might not necessarily react to straight away. And then they increase the scale of it. The question here is where are those red lines that NATO and Western partners of Ukraine said would be crossed if Russia uses the chemical weapons?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: And also, what will they do then if those are crossed?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Exactly what will they do.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Sasha Vakulina, thank you as always for updating us on the latest from the war in Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Thank you so much.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Well, as the shadow of war looms over the east of Ukraine, aid agencies are doing what they can to help people who flee their homes, as well as those who choose to stay on. Well, the ICRC spokesperson in Ukraine, Lucille Marbeau, joins us now to explain what's happening in Dnipro. Ms. Marbeau, thanks so much for joining us on the program tonight. So how bad is the situation then on the ground in Dnipro? Are you able to get those much needed supplies in and out?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: So fortunately, Dnipro has been, since the escalation of the conflict at the end of February, a safe haven for many, many people fleeing frontline cities. So people here have been transiting from Kharkiv, from the east, from Severodonetsk, Lisichansk, densely populated areas. We're seeing an influx right now of people arriving from the east, but also people from the east, from Severodonetsk, Lysychansk, densely populated areas.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: We're seeing an influx right now of people arriving from the east, but also people from the south in Mariupol.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: So what we're doing here is really assisting shelters where people are staying.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: So it's really giving the basics.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: It's going to be food, water, hygiene items, mattresses, blankets, everything they need.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: And next to the train station, for instance, there is a shelter where people often overnight, for those especially who really want to flee further west to safety, but also to join family members who are further west or who also maybe are in neighboring countries. So our work here in Dnipro is really to assist those who are fleeing the hard-hit areas.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: So let's come to the opening then of humanitarian corridors out of Mariupol.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: We know that it's been difficult, but you were also involved in a convoy that evacuated people from Zaporizhia.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: How precarious was that?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Well, so we were fortunately able to lead to safety around 1,000 civilians from Berdyansk to Zaporizhzhia.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Many came from Mariupol.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: And what they told us was really dire.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Many of them leave the city walking.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: So they're exposing themselves to extreme danger, as hostilities are ongoing.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Our team was 20 kilometers away from Mariupol. But because of the security situation there, we could see that there was ongoing fighting. Of course, we couldn't access the city directly.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: And as we know, and this is unfortunately everywhere, when there's armed conflict, hostilities in cities, truce is always precarious. It's very fragile. So you can have an agreement on the top with, between the capitals for safe passage for civilians, but then in the ground you see that there is actually hostilities ongoing.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: So regarding those that we were able to assist from Mariupol, they were saying that the humanitarian situation was absolutely terrible. Of course, for, there has been no water, no food, no electricity, no medication, no access, of course, to health services, and barely any connectivity.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: And for those who boarded our buses, we had seven buses, 350 people boarded them, mostly elderly families.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Also, private cars joined us, seven at the beginning.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: It was 100 cars in the end, so around 1,000 civilians who really joined the convoy because there's the symbol of the Red Cross, the emblem of protection, bringing them to safety. So the people were relieved, really, when they were boarding the buses. But many also were telling us that they had left family behind.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: And as there's barely any connectivity, how can they know if they're safe and well?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: How can they know if they're still alive?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: So the people are immensely relieved.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: They have also, I mean, they're very weak physically, psychologically, of course, but at least now they're safe.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: But they're extremely worried, of course, for the families that they have left behind.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Exactly. I mean, the situation that you paint on the ground is quite desperate.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Now, we're seeing figures today from the UN that 4.5 million children have been displaced since the start of this war.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: So for those children then that you are helping, are they able to process what is happening to them?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Well, of course, these children, as the families themselves, need, of course, psychosocial support, because they have gone really through a lot.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Our concern also is for unaccompanied minors. So, when I was on the convoy, there were two unaccompanied minors. And there was one 14-year-old teenager who had basically been sent away by her parents, staying in Mariupol, to her brother in Zaporizhzhia.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: So now she's safe, because she's with her brother.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: But, of course, this girl was really exposed to immense danger, traveling on her own.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: She left the city walking.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: And these are immediate safety concerns, of course, when we know that some children are traveling alone and need, of course, utmost protection in that case.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: So what also we do, of course, is really answer the first needs of children. It's going to be things as simple as diapers, because people can't purchase them. They don't necessarily have the money. And, of course, assist the parents, because if the parents feel secure, the child, of course, the parents because if the parents feel secure the child of course will also feel secure the children will usually really also feel the anxiety the distress of the parents and this is going to have an immediate effect impact on them directly so the safer the parents feel of course it's going to help also the child to feel safe himself. Indeed. Lucille Marbeau, ICRC spokesperson in Ukraine, thank you so much for updating us on the situation as you tried to help people on the ground fleeing this war in Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Thank you so much.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Now, at least five people have been shot at a subway station in Brooklyn.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: US authorities have confirmed.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Our team in the Cube have been working to verify what we know about this incident so far.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Let's find out more with Matthew.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: This incident occurred during Tuesday morning rush hour inside a New York City borough.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: A police spokeswoman confirmed that officers were called to an incident in southern Brooklyn inside a subway station at around 8.27 local time.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: We now know that at least 16 people were injured in this incident.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: That includes 10 people who suffered gunshot wounds. Five of those are now reported to be in a critical but stable condition and there are no indications of any life-threatening injuries. A fire department spokesperson also said that smoke had filled the station. Graphic images from the scene which we won't be showing you, they show passengers bloodied and lying on the floor being tended to inside this Brooklyn subway station. And as you can see from pictures outside the subway station as well, there was a vast emergency service personnel. We know the authorities have cordoned off the scene while an investigation is underway and people are urged to avoid the area. There is still very little indication or early information about any motives or any suspects in this incident. But the New York City Police Commissioner has now told reporters that a suspect wearing a constructive type vest put on a gas mask before opening a canister and then opening fire on the train. The incident is not being treated as terrorism related at this stage, but authorities are investigating and the New York City Mayor, State Governor and President Joe Biden are all also monitoring the situation.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: There were also reports of unexploded explosive or smoke devices inside the station, but we now know that New York City Police Department have confirmed there are no active explosives at this stage. Here in the Cube, Maria, we'll keep you updated on this active shooting incident inside a Brooklyn subway station in New York City. Okay, Matthew, thank you for updating us there on that incident.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson and his Chancellor Rishi Sunak have been fined for attending parties during the Covid-19 lockdown.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: London's Metropolitan Police handed out more than 50 fixed penalty notices as part of its investigation into unlawful gatherings held by the government while lockdown measures were in place.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Johnson and Sunak are the first Prime Minister and Chancellor to have been fined for breaking the law while in office.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: The leader of the opposition, Labour Party Keir Starmer, has called for both Johnson and Sunak to step down, joining a growing list of lawmakers demanding their resignations.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: The First Ministers of Scotland and Wales have also said that the Prime Minister and his Chancellor must go.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Boris Johnson has repeatedly denied breaking any lockdown laws which has led to his opponents to accuse him of misleading Parliament. Well back in January the Prime Minister apologised for the way the situation was handled.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Take a look.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: But firstly, I want to say sorry.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: And I'm sorry for the things we simply didn't get right.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: And also sorry for the way that this matter has been handled.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: And it's no use saying that this or that was within the rules.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: And it's no use saying that people were working hard this pandemic was hard for everyone we asked people across this country to make the most extraordinary sacrifices not to meet loved ones not to visit relatives before they died and i understand the anger that people feel well our reporter tag enright joins us now from now from London for the latest. Tyeke, good to see you. So Boris Johnson is a first sitting Prime Minister to be fined for breaking the law. Richard Sunak the first Chancellor to be fined. Now they've both previously denied to Parliament that they attended any parties. Are their positions now untenable?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Well we've not actually heard from either of them as of yet, but I think all indications are that Prime Minister Boris Johnson has no intention of resigning or going easily.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: He won't be following those calls from opposition leaders and leaders of the UK nations to do so.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: And arguably, he's in a stronger position now than he was earlier this year when this scandal reached its climax.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Firstly, because the Chancellor, Rishi Sunak, as you mentioned there, he was then seen as the primary challenger to Boris Johnson.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Now he's been shown to be a lawbreaker too, and he's been battling his own separate political problems because of the tax status of his very, very wealthy wife.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: So the threat from him has been neutralised. That leaves it next of all to Conservative MPs to potentially stick the knife in. Many of them expressed truly heartfelt outrage at the scandal of Downing Street lockdown parties when the scandal broke a few months ago. But now even Boris Johnson's worst critics within the party, the leader of the party in Scotland, Douglas Ross, who first called on him to resign, has said that now, because of the war in Ukraine, is not a time for a change in leadership, even though some critics have pointed out that Britain during World War II did replace Neville Chamberlain with Winston Churchill as prime minister.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: But the one weakness in Boris Johnson's position is that there could be a drip-drip effect going on here.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: This is just one fine for one party.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: We know he's suspected of being at other parties, so there could be yet more fines to come, and that could escalate the pressure upon him.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: OK, so, Ty, you mentioned there that there's no intention to resign just yet.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: But let's talk about these local elections that are coming up in May.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Many in the Conservative Party, of course, fear a fallout from the so-called Partygate scandal.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: So how important do you think voters consider these local elections to be?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Well, they're very important and certainly they're a barometer of voter opinion.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: And of course, while local elections don't influence government per se they're effectively an opinion poll ahead of the next general election which some people think there's uh preparations for to hold to take place next year you know a few weeks ago a poll of voters here suggested that a majority wanted boris johnson to resign if

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: he was indeed fined for these parties. Now that has indeed happened. Now we're heading into these elections in a few weeks time, which if nothing changes, the Conservative Party will have been shown to be sitting on their hands with a law-breaking prime minister at the helm. And there will be inevitably a fresh wave of storytelling, contrast between what people were doing at all those moments in their personal lives during lockdown, perhaps not seeing loved ones who are dying in hospital at a time when Boris Johnson and his officials were having parties in Downing Street. You know the Brexit wave of support which brought Boris Johnson to power, which won him the biggest majority that his party has known in a generation generation is clearly over.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Now he's dealing with a cost of living crisis of historic proportions and, of course, an historic scandal of lawbreaking at the very heart of government. But cast your mind forward to a few weeks' time, and even if those local election results are bad, nobody expects the war in Ukraine to end any time soon, so the same arguments will prevail then that perhaps now is not the time for a change in leadership.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Mariam?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: OK, Ty, we'll leave it there, but thank you for projecting us on these difficult times ahead for the Prime Minister and his party.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Thank you so much.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Now, switching gears, Sri Lanka's government has taken the dramatic step of suspending payments on its $25 billion in international debts, with $7 billion in repayments due this year.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Protesters aimed much of their anger at the ruling Rajapaksa family, who have been in power for two decades.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Ordinary families have faced shortages of food, fuel and other essentials.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: The government's loan repayments are being halted while the International Monetary Fund organises a bailout plan.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: US inflation is growing at its fastest pace in more than 40 years. Consumer prices jumped by 8.5% in March as the previous year, making it the biggest year-on-year increase since 1981.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Petrol is also up 48% and food is up 10%. Economists say the sharp rise is due to the supply chain disruptions made worse by the war in Ukraine, coupled with high consumer demand.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: 263 million more people could be living in extreme poverty by the end of this year, according to a new report from Oxfam.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: The aid agency is also warning that millions are now facing mass starvation across East Africa, the Sahel, Yemen and Syria.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Oxfam says the situation has been aggravated by rising inflation, the COVID-19 pandemic and the war in Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: inflation the COVID-19 pandemic and the war in Ukraine. The Champions League quarter-finals second legs get underway this evening. Holders Chelsea have to do

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: it all as they travel to Spanish giants Real Madrid. Thomas Tuchel's side are 3-1 down from the first leg. Now in the other tie in the last of the eight tie Villarreal are away to Bayern in munich the spanish holder one nil advantage over the german champions heading into tonight's fixture now veterinary hospitals in kiev are on a mission to save pets that have been left behind one such clinic has

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: tended to hundreds of injured cats and dogs since the beginning of the war and is urging animal lovers provide them with a new home. Sergio Ferreira de Almeida reports now. Take a look.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: While Ukrainian citizens are enduring unimaginable suffering, their animals are also victims of the war. Many have died in explosions, others of starvation. They have been exposed to the same horrors as the human owners.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: And those who have survived, like these dogs in Borodyanka, are now abandoned.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: A Kiev veterinary clinic with dozens of volunteers is helping to change the course of these stories.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Since the beginning of the war in Ukraine, it has rescued hundreds of pets.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Our mission is to help dogs who come to us from different cities, from Bucha, from Erpin, from Gostomel, who lost their home, who lost their owner. Oh! Their first owners.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: And save them.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: And when they will be healthy we already take it to new home.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Or maybe find old home.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: And save as many lives of dogs and cats as it's only possible.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: They arrive angry and wounded with bomb fragments. They receive all the treatment that they need and after everything that they have been through these animals have the chance of a new life, a new home.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: We are working as volunteer photographers and make photos of all animals for the site of this clinic and everybody can choose the animal and grab it to their home.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: All the rooms of this clinic are always full of pets and volunteers because dogs and cats must be accompanied 24 hours a day. And every day more animals are arriving.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Sergio Ferreira Dalmeida in Kiev for Euronews.
